title: Larry Kudlow
deleted: In 1993, Kudlow claimed that [[Bill Clinton]]'s tax increases would dampen economic growth.<ref name=":1" /> When the economy boomed in the late-1990s, Kudlow credited it to tax cuts enacted during the [[Presidency of Ronald Reagan|Reagan administration (1981–1989)]].<ref name=":1" />

title: Larry Kudlow
deleted: On February 25, 2020, as a [[COVID-19 pandemic|coronavirus pandemic]] was emerging as a global pandemic, Kudlow stated, "We have contained this, I won't say airtight but pretty close to airtight."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/02/25/kudlow-white-house-coronavirus-117402 |title=Kudlow breaks with CDC on coronavirus: 'We have contained this' |first=Eli |last=Okun |work=[[Politico]] |date=February 25, 2020 |access-date=June 15, 2020 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200605111203/https://www.politico.com/news/2020/02/25/kudlow-white-house-coronavirus-117402 |archive-date=June 5, 2020}}</ref>

title: Larry Kudlow
deleted: Also in April, Kudlow alleged that [[United States Ambassador to the United Nations|U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations]] [[Nikki Haley]] had announced that the U.S. would soon sanction [[Russia]] due to "momentary confusion". After Haley contradicted Kudlow's claim, Kudlow called Haley to apologize.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/white-house/larry-kudlow-apologizes-nikki-haley-over-russia-sanctions-remark-n866916|title=Larry Kudlow apologizes to Nikki Haley over Russia sanctions remark|last=Associated Press|date=2018-04-18|work=NBC News|access-date=2018-04-18|language=en-US}}</ref>

As Trump celebrated the six-month anniversary of the tax cut on June 29, 2018, Kudlow falsely asserted that the tax cut was generating such growth that "the deficit, which was one of the other criticisms, is coming down – and it's coming down rapidly."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2018/06/29/larry-kudlow-and-the-white-house-now-claim-the-growing-deficit-is-actually-dropping-and-rapidly/|title=Analysis | Trump’s top economic adviser makes a laughable claim about a very basic economic number|first1=Aaron|last=Blake|website=Washington Post}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://politi.co/2KmSG1z|title=Kudlow explains himself|first1=Ben|last1=White|first2=Aubree Eliza|last2=Weaver|website=POLITICO}}</ref> [[Kevin Hassett]], chairman of Trump's [[Council of Economic Advisers]], noted days earlier that the deficit was "skyrocketing", which is consistent with the analysis of every reputable budget analyst.<ref name="wpclaim">{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2018/06/29/larry-kudlow-and-the-white-house-now-claim-the-growing-deficit-is-actually-dropping-and-rapidly/|title=Analysis – Trump’s top economic adviser makes a laughable claim about a very basic economic number|last=Blake|first=Aaron|date=June 29, 2018|work=Washington Post|accessdate=June 29, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=https://fred.stlouisfed.org/graph/?g=kkpF|title=Federal Surplus or Deficit |date=June 12, 2018|publisher=|accessdate=July 3, 2018}}</ref> Kudlow later asserted he was referring to future deficits, although every credible budget forecast indicates increasing deficits in coming years, made worse by the Trump tax cut if not offset by major spending cuts. Barring such spending cuts, the CBO projected the tax cut would add $1.27 trillion in deficits over the next decade, even after considering any economic growth the tax cut might generate.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2018/06/29/trumps-top-economic-adviser-says-deficit-is-coming-down-rapidly-contradicting-all-available-data/ |title=Analysis – Trump's top economic adviser says deficit 'is coming down rapidly', contradicting virtually all available data |first=Jeff |last=Stein |date=June 29, 2018 |accessdate=July 1, 2018 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]}}</ref>

In November 2018, eleven months after the Trump tax cut, Kudlow stated, “the tax cut has paid for itself already barely through the first calendar year,” although data released weeks later showed federal revenue had declined and the deficit had increased during calendar 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.realclearpolitics.com/video/2018/11/15/larry_kudlow_tax_cut_has_paid_for_itself_already_through_higher_tax_revenue.html|title=Larry Kudlow: Tax Cut Has Paid For Itself Already Through Higher Tax Revenue And Growth|website=www.realclearpolitics.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/11/business/trump-tax-cuts-revenue.html |title=It's Official: The Trump Tax Cuts Didn't Pay for Themselves in Year One |first=Jim |last=Tankersley |date=January 11, 2019 |newspaper=The New York Times}}</ref>

On February 25, 2020, as a [[COVID-19 pandemic|coronavirus pandemic]] was emerging as a global pandemic, Kudlow stated, "We have contained this, I won't say airtight but pretty close to airtight."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/02/25/kudlow-white-house-coronavirus-117402 |title=Kudlow breaks with CDC on coronavirus: 'We have contained this' |first=Eli |last=Okun |work=[[Politico]] |date=February 25, 2020 |access-date=June 15, 2020 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200605111203/https://www.politico.com/news/2020/02/25/kudlow-white-house-coronavirus-117402 |archive-date=June 5, 2020}}</ref>
